heading: Definitions
description: Definitions related to HITECH privacy provisions and key terms
content_summary: Defines critical terms including unsecured PHI breach compromise presumption low risk of compromise business associate direct liability and related enforcement concepts used throughout HITECH Act
key_concepts: Unsecured PHI, Breach definition, Compromise presumption, Low risk threshold, Business associate, Subcontractor, Direct liability, Electronic PHI

heading: Breach Notification
description: Notification in case of breach of unsecured protected health information
content_summary: Comprehensive breach notification requirements establishing mandatory notification of individuals within 60 calendar days discovery of breach of unsecured PHI includes individual media and HHS notification procedures timeline and content requirements
key_concepts: Breach discovery, 60-day timeline, Individual notification, Media notification (500+), HHS notification, Unsecured PHI, Risk assessment, Four-factor test, Compromise presumption, Safe harbor provisions

heading: Notification by Business Associates
description: Requirements for business associates to notify covered entities of breaches
content_summary: Business associates must notify covered entities of any breach of unsecured PHI without unreasonable delay and no later than 60 calendar days from discovery of breach included detailed breach information for covered entity to issue individual notifications
key_concepts: Business associate notification, Covered entity notification, 60-day timeline, Detailed breach information, Affected individuals list, PHI categories, Mitigation steps, Investigation results

heading: Business Associate Agreements
description: Requirements for business associate agreements and compliance
content_summary: HITECH requires covered entities to ensure business associates and all subcontractors comply with HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules establishes direct liability for business associates and requires written business associate agreements with specified terms and conditions
key_concepts: Business Associate Agreement, Direct liability, Subcontractor liability, BAA requirements, Compliance obligations, Minimum necessary, Uses and disclosures, Safeguard implementation, Breach reporting, Termination clauses

heading: Civil Monetary Penalties
description: Tiered civil monetary penalties for HIPAA violations
content_summary: HITECH established four-tier penalty framework for HIPAA violations scaled to culpability level Tier 1 unknowing violations $100-50000 per violation Tier 2 reasonable cause $1000-50000 Tier 3 willful neglect corrected $10000-50000 Tier 4 willful neglect not corrected $20000-50000 with $1.5M annual cap
key_concepts: Tier 1 unknowing violation, Tier 2 reasonable cause, Tier 3 willful neglect (corrected), Tier 4 willful neglect (not corrected), Penalty ranges, Annual caps, Mitigating factors, Corrective action plans, Penalty assessment

heading: Enforcement Activities of Secretary
description: HHS enforcement authority and procedures for HIPAA compliance
content_summary: OCR enforcement authority to investigate HIPAA complaints conduct periodic compliance audits issue penalties issue warning letters require corrective action plans audit both covered entities and business associates with same enforcement procedures and authority expanded from original HIPAA
key_concepts: OCR investigation authority, Compliance audits, Desk audits, On-site audits, Penalty authority, Corrective action plans, Warning letters, Notice of violation, Evidence collection, Subpoena authority

heading: Business Associate Requirements
description: Specific requirements for business associates regarding safeguards and breach notification
content_summary: Business associates must implement HIPAA Privacy and Security Rule safeguards conduct regular risk assessments maintain audit logs provide breach notification to covered entities and maintain documentation of compliance efforts business associates directly liable for HIPAA violations and subject to same penalties as covered entities
key_concepts: Business associate safeguards, Risk assessment requirement, Audit logging, Breach notification, Direct liability, Same penalties as covered entities, Compliance documentation, Security measures implementation, Training requirements

heading: Criminal Penalties
description: Criminal penalties for knowing HIPAA violations
content_summary: HITECH establishes criminal liability for knowing HIPAA violations obtaining or disclosing PHI under false pretenses with commercial advantage or private gain criminal penalties up to $250000 fine and or 10 years imprisonment for single knowing violation multiple years imprisonment for multiple violations
key_concepts: Knowing violation, Commercial advantage, Private gain, Criminal penalties, $250,000 fine, 10-year imprisonment, Multiple offenses, False pretenses, Department of Justice referral

heading: Accounting of Disclosures
description: Enhanced accounting of disclosures requirements
content_summary: HITECH expands accounting of disclosures requirement to 3 years for covered entities and business associates must track all uses and disclosures of PHI provide detailed accounting including date recipient purpose and type of information individual can request accounting at any time covered entity must provide within 30 days
key_concepts: 3-year accounting history, All disclosures tracked, Detailed accounting content, Recipient identification, Purpose of disclosure, PHI type disclosed, Accounting request procedure, 30-day response timeline

heading: Restrictions on Use and Disclosure
description: Requirements for restricting uses and disclosures of PHI
content_summary: Individuals have enhanced right to request restrictions on use and disclosure of PHI covered entity must implement appropriate restrictions business associate must comply with use and disclosure restrictions contained in business associate agreement applies minimum necessary standard to all uses and disclosures
key_concepts: Use restrictions, Disclosure restrictions, Individual requests, Restriction implementation, Minimum necessary standard, Business associate compliance, Covered entity obligations

heading: Certified EHR Technology
description: Requirements for certified electronic health record technology
content_summary: Office of National Coordinator establishes standards for certifying EHR systems certified EHR must meet functional security and privacy requirements establish testing procedures and maintain authoritative list of certified systems EHR vendors must develop systems meeting certification standards and undergo certification testing
key_concepts: ONC certification standards, EHR functional requirements, Security requirements, Privacy requirements, Testing procedures, Certified system list, Vendor certification, Compliance testing, Interoperability requirements

heading: Grants for Health Information Technology
description: Grants and financial resources for healthcare providers to adopt EHR systems and support health IT implementation and workforce development
content_summary: HHS and CMS provide grants to eligible healthcare providers and organizations for EHR adoption implementation and training grants support acquisition implementation workforce training and infrastructure development to accelerate health IT adoption across healthcare

heading: Loans for Health Information Technology
description: Loan programs for healthcare organizations to finance EHR adoption and implementation costs and related health IT infrastructure development
content_summary: HHS and CMS establish loan programs for eligible healthcare providers with favorable terms to finance EHR and health IT implementation loans support technology acquisition system integration and infrastructure development to reduce capital barriers to EHR adoption

heading: Workforce Development for Health Information Technology
description: Funding for workforce development training and education programs for healthcare IT professionals and clinical staff to support EHR adoption and health IT implementation
content_summary: CMS and HHS support development and delivery of training curricula for health IT professionals clinical informatics training clinical staff training and organizational change management training to develop qualified workforce to support EHR systems development testing implementation and operations

heading: Enforcement Actions and Corrective Actions
description: Requirements for corrective action plans and enforcement procedures when HIPAA violations are identified
content_summary: OCR requires covered entities and business associates to develop and implement corrective action plans to remediate identified violations corrective action plans must include root cause analysis remediation steps implementation timeline responsible parties and success metrics OCR monitors implementation and verifies compliance
key_concepts: Corrective action plans, Root cause analysis, Remediation procedures, Timeline requirements, Implementation monitoring, Compliance verification, Success metrics, CAP modifications

heading: Privacy and Security Rules Enhancements
description: Enhancements to HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules through HITECH
content_summary: HITECH enhances HIPAA Privacy Rule with expanded individual rights mandatory breach notification extended accounting requirements and strengthened restrictions on use and disclosure HITECH enhances Security Rule with mandatory risk assessment requirements encryption standards access control requirements audit logging requirements and incident response requirements
key_concepts: Risk assessment (mandatory), Encryption standards, Access controls, Audit logging, Incident response, Individual rights, Breach notification, Minimum necessary standard, Privacy training

heading: Safe Harbor Amendment Recognized Security Practices
description: Penalty mitigation for organizations implementing recognized security practices as of January 5 2021 amendment
content_summary: OCR may reduce or waive penalties for Tier 3 willful neglect violations if entity demonstrated implementation of recognized security practices from NIST Cybersecurity Framework or HHS 45 CFR 164.308(a)(7) guidance for 12 months prior to breach violation recognized practices include encryption standards access controls audit logging key management risk assessment incident response
key_concepts: Recognized security practices, NIST CSF compliance, HHS 405(d) guidance, Implementation period (12+ months), Penalty reduction/waiver, Encryption (AES-256, TLS 1.2+), MFA requirements, Audit logging (6+ years)

heading: State Attorney General Authority
description: State-level enforcement authority under HIPAA and HITECH for consumer protection and health information privacy violations
content_summary: State attorneys general have authority to pursue civil actions for HIPAA and HITECH violations affecting state residents state AGs can recover actual damages statutory damages up to $100 per violation court costs and attorney fees state AGs also have authority to pursue public health and consumer protection actions for information privacy breaches
key_concepts: Civil action authority, State resident jurisdiction, Actual damages, Statutory damages, Court costs, Attorney fees, Public health authority, Consumer protection, Coordination with federal enforcement

heading: EHR Testing and Certification Standards
description: ONC testing and certification standards for electronic health record systems and health IT modules
content_summary: ONC establishes comprehensive testing and certification standards for EHR systems and health IT modules testing procedures validate compliance with functional requirements security standards privacy standards and interoperability requirements certified EHR systems must meet these standards to qualify for meaningful use incentive payments and federal procurement
key_concepts: Testing standards, Functional requirements, Security testing, Privacy testing, Interoperability testing, Certification criteria, Certified system list, Annual recertification, Version updates, Module certification

heading: EHR Incentive Payments Meaningful Use
description: Medicare and Medicaid incentive payments for eligible providers adopting certified EHR technology and achieving meaningful use objectives
content_summary: CMS administers EHR incentive programs providing Medicare and Medicaid payments to eligible providers hospitals and critical access hospitals for adopting certified EHR systems and demonstrating meaningful use of EHR technology meaningful use requires demonstrating clinical objectives administrative objectives and interoperability objectives to qualify for incentive payments payments decrease after 2015 and phase out transitioning to promoting interoperability program and MIPS framework
key_concepts: Eligibility criteria, Incentive payment amounts, Meaningful use objectives, Clinical objectives, Administrative objectives, Interoperability objectives, Attestation requirements, Payment schedules, Transition to MIPS

heading: Coordinated Enforcement Procedures
description: Coordinated enforcement procedures between HHS OCR and State Attorneys General for HIPAA and HITECH violations
content_summary: HHS OCR and state attorneys general coordinate enforcement efforts to avoid duplication and ensure consistent enforcement of HIPAA and HITECH requirements OCR handles federal enforcement and penalty assessment state AGs pursue state-level civil actions through coordination agreement entities may be subject to both federal and state enforcement actions for significant violations
key_concepts: Coordination procedures, Federal enforcement, State enforcement, Dual enforcement, Settlement coordination, Information sharing, Mutual recognition of settlements
authority: HHS Office for Civil Rights (OCR) and State Attorneys General

heading: Subcontractor Accountability
description: Direct HIPAA liability of subcontractors engaged by business associates and healthcare organizations
content_summary: HITECH extends direct HIPAA liability to all subcontractors and downstream vendors engaged by business associates subcontractors must be subject to HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules and have contractual agreements flowing down compliance obligations business associates remain responsible for monitoring subcontractor compliance with HIPAA requirements
key_concepts: Subcontractor definition, Direct liability, Written agreements required, Flow-down requirements, Compliance obligations, Monitoring requirements, Breach notification (60-day), Enforcement authority

heading: Mitigating Factors in Penalty Assessment
description: Factors OCR considers when determining HIPAA violation penalties and penalty amounts
content_summary: OCR considers multiple mitigating factors when assessing civil monetary penalties including good faith compliance efforts nature and extent of violation degree of culpability organizational size prior violation history implementation of recognized security practices prompt correction upon discovery cooperation with OCR investigation financial hardship and duration of violation these factors may result in penalty reduction within assessed tier ranges
key_concepts: Good faith efforts, Violation nature, Culpability degree, Organization size, Prior violations, Security practices, Prompt correction, OCR cooperation, Financial hardship, Violation duration
